intro: Moquilea tomentosa, commonly known as the woolly moquilea, is a flowering plant native to the Canary Islands. It belongs to the family Acanthaceae and is characterized by its hairy, grayish foliage and showy, tubular flowers that range in color from pink to red. The plant thrives in coastal and rocky environments, often growing in well-drained soils. Its unique appearance makes it a popular ornamental plant in subtropical gardens. Moquilea tomentosa is also noted for its ability to withstand drought and salt spray, making it well-suited for coastal regions.
